testimony: The application of this applicant appears in volume 1 from page 23 Mr Chairman.
Mr Raath you are an applicant applying for amnesty for any criminal or legal deed which was committed by you regarding the incident where Mr Kondile was killed, is that correct?

In your application on page 23 paragraph 7A and B, you replied "not applicable, and not applicable" to questions as to whether you were, amongst others, a member of a political organisation, institution or body, and if so in what capacity, that information you say to me is wrong.  Paragraph 7A which are the correct facts that we can say there?  Were  you a member of any political organisation?

Mr Chairman I must tell you, and you will find this with many, many applicants the question here has been put, it's very unclear and it seems to be directed at officials of a particular organisation.  Certainly that is the way my attorney read it, he tells me.
"Lid", well I've just asked this witness and he says he wasn't a "lid".
Was a supporter, the following word?
I would ask Mr Chairman, I would move Mr Chairman for an amendment of the application in that regard.  7A should read "National Party" - "supporter" and 7B should read "National Party".
Thank you Mr Chairman.  Mr Chairman is it correct that on the 21st of January 1968 you became a member of the South African Police?
And that from the 22nd of January 1968 up to and including December 1973 you were at the Uniform Branch?
And is it also correct that from 1973 to 1975 you were a detective?
And from '75 you became involved in the Security Branch?
Is it also so that from January '89 you were transferred to the Eastern Cape, Port Elizabeth where you lived?
Yes.  He arrived here one month after Gerrit Erasmus Mr Chairman.
And that you lived in Port Elizabeth until January '82 when you were transferred to Natal?
And that you lived in Natal until December 1989?
Thereafter from January 1990 till December '92 you were stationed in Bloemfontein in the Free State?
And thereafter till the 30th of March 1997 you were in Port Shepstone, in the stabilising unit, the unrest unit?
And on the 30th of March '97 you left the services of the South African Police Force?
Where were you born and where did you grow up?
I was born in Pretoria and I grew up there till I was five years old and then we moved to the Eastern Transvaal.
Very briefly what was the background of your education milieu?

I grew up in a very conservative Afrikaans household and my parents were supporters of the National party and this is how I grew up.  We were also member of the NG Church.  My parents were supporters of the National Party's policy of apartheid, we believed in that.  Apart from opposition speeches and press there were very few things that made me think that I was wrong in this respect.
And when you were a policeman you took an oath of trust in the government?
And as security policemen did you have anything to do with internal security?

You heard the testimony of du Plessis, van Rensburg and Erasmus, especially Erasmus regarding the matters regarding the unrest situation in Port Elizabeth in the years '80 and '81, was it also your experience regarding the situation there?
How would you have described the situation, how would you describe it today if you had to tell it in one sentence, how were things during those years, the situation in Port Elizabeth?

I regarded it as something that had got out of hand.  The conditions in and around Port Elizabeth was that the security situation was out of control.  There were problems with the fact that the normal, the ordinary policeman could not do his duties effectively.  Policemen were a constant target for attacks....(intervention)
Just a bit slower please.  You say that the policemen were a constant target for attacks and murder?

Yes.  This resulted in the fact that law and order could not be maintained and applied properly.  The result of this was a tremendous increase in normal, ordinary crime, together with a low success rate of court-orientated actions.  There was an inability to protect human lives and property.
We've already learnt from Mr Erasmus that the role players or some of the big role players here like students and scholars and the workers, they were the biggest component?

To save time he also referred to resistance actions which took place there and in general he informed the Committee regarding consumer boycotts, the burning of beer halls and large-scale intimidation, was that also your experience?

You confirm Mr Erasmus and du Plessis and van Rensburg's testimony in this regard, regarding the general circumstances.
	Now if we can go direct to Mr Sizwe Kondile's matter.  I want you, as far as you can remember, and if you can't remember certain aspects from memory just tell me, please tell us what exactly you had to do with Mr Kondile?  I am sorry, first I want to ask what was your rank in 1981?
So you were functioning on grassroots level?
I was involved in Kondile's interrogation.
Mr Raath I think I have to lead you in this regard.  Mr Kondile was detained in the Free State, you know that?
Do you know how he landed in the Eastern Cape then?
I received an instruction from Captain du Plessis to fetch Kondile and to transport him to Port Elizabeth.
Where did you place Kondile or what happened to him after you had brought him from Bloemfontein?
I took him to the police cells in Humansdorp where I detained him, and I reported that to Captain du Plessis.
If I might ask Mr Raath, who accompanied you to Bloemfontein?
I was accompanied by Capt Greyling who also worked in Port Elizabeth.
Was Mr Danster with you when you went to fetch Sizwe Kondile?

After I detained him I informed Capt du Plessis that he was being detained at Humansdorp.   Later Sizwe Kondile was transferred to Jeffrey's Bay where the interrogation continued.
	I was at all times in contact with du Plessis.  Sometimes we jointly interrogated him, sometimes I was alone, he was alone.
Here is a person by the name of Danster who made an affidavit, do you know this person?
During this time relevant to Mr Kondile's detention at Jeffrey's Bay he was working at the same security branch in Port Elizabeth as I.
Mr Danster, according to your knowledge, did he interrogate Mr Kondile?
And according to what you can remember, when did Mr Danster, for the first time, have anything to do with Mr Kondile?
It was after I had received an instruction from du Plessis that Kondile should be detained in the barracks.
That is what has been referred to as the white single quarters?
Then Mr Danster was brought to assist you so that there would always be one person with Mr Kondile?
Mr Raath did you ever assault Mr Kondile?
And if you had done that are you aware that you could apply for amnesty for that?
Did you ever see Mr Danster assaulting Mr Kondile?
In any case you were busy saying that you also participated in Mr Kondile's interrogation, what else do you want to add to that?

I can just mention that during the time of his detention Kondile conveyed certain information to us, he identified certain things.  One important identification was in Transkei.  We took him there and he identified two people working in a bank and if I can remember now they were his contact persons who during the smuggling of explosives ...(intervention)
Mr Chairman forgive me for asking you but would you switch off your microphone please.

Thank you.  Well it wasn't you that was making the noise, I think it's my witness that is making the noise.  Please don't touch the microphone please.
	Can you remember who those persons were who were identified by Kondile in Transkei regarding the smuggling of explosives?
I can't remember their names now.
But there was an attempt to arrest them but they got away we've heard that evidence.
Regarding you, what was Mr Kondile's status, did he belong to any organisation according to your information?

Yes during my interrogation of Kondile it was evident that he was a trained terrorist.   And also a courier between Lesotho, Transkei and the Republic.  And that he was trusted by Chris Hani.  He was an MK commander.
And would you say that Mr Kondile was also, besides being a confidante of Chris Hani also a member of the ANC?
Sizwe Kondile was also, besides being a confidante of Chris Hani, also a member of the ANC, he was a trained terrorist.
Is it correct to say that you became aware that Mr du Plessis was busy to recruit Mr Kondile as an informer?
Yes, that is what he told me, that he was busy to have long discussions with Kondile and to recruit him as an informer.
From that moment what was your contact with Mr Kondile afterwards?
After du Plessis had told me that he was recruiting him as an informer I withdrew.
It was the general practice at the security branch that you do not interfere with somebody else's informer.
An informer has either one or two handlers, you were not one of them?
You also became aware that something had gone wrong with the deployment of Mr Kondile as an informer.  What was mentioned to you.

Capt du Plessis approached me and told me that he found that Kondile was smuggling information from the cells to the ANC.  He did not provide any details.  That created a large problem because certain sensitive information regarding informers and information channels were conveyed to Kondile.  Because of this sensitivity of this matter it was decided that Kondile had to be eliminated.

In any case afterwards is it correct to say that Mr du Plessis spoke to you again regarding Mr Kondile, and here I refer to the instance when Kondile was already being detained in the white single quarters?

That was during the stage when he was in the single quarters, he told me or instructed me and Danster, after he had told me that information was being leaked and that would harm his intelligence network and he said that that person had to be detained there.  Nobody should have access to him and I should see that no information would leak from that quarter.
I just want to interrupt.  You later met Dirk Coetzee?
As far as you know was he at any stage in contact with Mr Kondile while he was being detained in the single quarters?
Afterwards Mr du Plessis approached you again ...(intervention)
Mr Visser I am not sure, but is the evidence that he was in the room with him or that he just passed by.

Mr Commissioner as we understand Coetzee's evidence, his provided evidence, he said that he and Nick van Rensburg went to the police cells in Jeffrey's Bay and he gave evidence that he and van Rensburg walked down a passage and there in one room he found two people.  One was a black security officer ...(intervention)
Yes I know he went down the passage, I just think he passed by the door and I ...(intervention)

I think your question to this witness was not that, your question was did Dirk Coetzee have contact with Kondile, and he says no he didn't have contact.  It was never put that Dirk Coetzee had contact with Kondile.

Thank you for pointing that out to me Mr Chairman, it's my mistake, I stand corrected and I appreciate it.
	Mr Raath while you were busy with Mr Kondile to guard him according to instructions, did you ever see Mr Dirk Coetzee with Mr Kondile?

Thank you Mr Chairman.
	Now Mr du Plessis talked to you again and what did he tell you?
Capt du Plessis gave an instruction in the form of a request.

He said he requested you to assist him.  He also afforded you the opportunity to consider the matter and a day or two afterwards you came back to him and said that you are prepared to help him.  You just said that you regarded that as an instruction rather than a request?
And exactly what did Mr du Plessis tell you?  Did he tell you that they had decided at a higher level that Mr Kondile had to be eliminated?
And what was the reason why you had to accompany them?
The reason was that I had to drive the vehicle with Kondile in from Bloemfontein on.
Let's be honest Mr Raath, can you remember the dates when those things took place from memory?
So we leave the dates aside.  On a specific day is it correct that you left with other people to Bloemfontein?
We travelled with Nick van Rensburg, Colonel du Plessis, the deceased Kondile and I myself.
And with whose vehicle did you travel?
If I remember well it was Capt du Plessis' vehicle.
You left from Port Elizabeth, can you remember at what time of the day it was?  Was it during the morning or the afternoon?
If I remember correctly it was early in the afternoon.
And then eventually you arrived in Bloemfontein.
Was it light or was it dark?
It was already late in the evening.
We went to a certain place I can't remember.  All I know was the vehicle was handed to me, that was Kondile's car.
Can you remember what type of car it was?
It was a light coloured Datsun.
That was handed to you there, do you remember by whom?
It could have been by Capt du Plessis or van Rensburg, one of them.
And did you then leave Bloemfontein at one or other time?
You are saying it's late in the evening and you were driving, who was in which vehicle?
Capt du Plessis, Colonel Nick van Rensburg and Kondile travelled in du Plessis' car and I drove Kondile's vehicle.
Who was in front and who was behind?
They were in front and I followed them.
No we could not because the vehicle was not in a good condition.
The Datsun was not in a good condition.
To cut a long story short, it was the next day the morning or that afternoon - first I want to say that.  O your way, you were travelling from Bloemfontein to where?
We were on our way to Komatipoort.
On your way to Komatipoort did you do anything to that Datsun vehicle?

Yes, near the border, I accept it's the Swaziland border there was a notice saying "Barberton".  I got instructions from van Rensburg to park the vehicle along the road and to leave it there with the keys in.
And what did you do then after you had parked it there?
I then got into the other vehicle and drove further with them.
Then you came to Komatipoort and what time of the day was that, was it the morning or the afternoon?
I think it was late in the afternoon.
And I think it can be said it's common cause that Mr Dirk Coetzee was there, you met him there?
Yes there was somebody with him.
Can you tell us today who that person was?
Your Honour I have met that man there for the first time in my life.  I have forgotten his name, but later on I established that it was Roy Otto.
Can you describe him for us as you remembered him?
I can vaguely remember that he was a short, stockish man, he had a bald head.
You met Mr Coetzee and that person to whom we will refer to as Mr Otto, for the purposes of your evidence, and what happened then?
From there I drove with du Plessis, van Rensburg and Kondile in the same vehicle and we followed Otto and Coetzee in their vehicle.
Was there anybody else, any other policeman there?
And once again, to cut a long story short, you drove into the bush and there you parked the vehicles and got out. What did you do then?
Well we got out of the vehicles and I saw that some wood had been gathered and at that stage I was extremely hungry and I gathered some more wood where we lit a fire and we prepared some food.
Mr Kondile, was he given any food?
And what happened in the meantime to him?

After we got out of the car he was sitting against a tree trunk and his hands were cuffed.  We gave him food to eat.  While we were standing around the fire Mr Coetzee offered him a drink or something.
I noticed that Kondile slowly fell to one side and I suspected then that he perhaps felt sleepy.  I did not realise precisely what was going to happen.
Did you hear later on that it was alleged that sleeping drugs, or drops were put into his drink, you were not aware of it then?
The next moment somebody said this matter must be concluded now and then suddenly this person, this Roy Otto walked up to Kondile, he drew his pistol and a shot rang out.
Did that shot kill Mr Kondile?
It's history now and I understand, I am not going into that in detail, but Mr Kondile's body was burnt to ashes.
And then eventually you returned to Port Elizabeth.
And is that the sum total of your participation in this unhappy incident?

Mr Chairman would you bear with me a moment.
	Mr Raath I've previously referred you to Mr Danster.  Mr Danter's statement is found in volume 1.  Yes thank you Mr Chairman but more specifically at page 49 the second paragraph.  This Mr Danster in his statement submitted - and that is at page 48 I believe Mr Chairman, that he would accompany these people with you, that he would accompany you with Kondile, that it had happened on a Friday and that you would spend the weekend somewhere.  Do you know anything about this, or whether Mr Danster was ever asked to accompany you on that occasion where you went to eliminate him?

It was not put in cross-examination either.  I continue to page 49 where Mr Danster says that when you returned you, Mr Raath, bragged about the fact that you had taught Mr Kondile a lesson.  And then he asked you what kind of lesson you are referring.  He said that you then said his brains were blown apart.  And then he drew the inference that Kondile had been eliminated.  What are you saying about Mr Danster's version?
Is there any sense in informing him about Mr Kondile's elimination?
No it's not something to brag about.
But if I might ask Mr Raath, you were there "he was shot in the head", am I wrong?
I can't say whether he was hit in his head, I did not see where the bullet penetrated.  I only saw him falling.  I was shocked, I did not know what to expect at that stage.

My recollection is that the evidence was he was either shot through the ear or through the head, there wasn't any real certainty.  Now whichever portion of the head, be it the ear or the head, unless I have a very over-imaginative, whatever, his brain would spat.  Now I am simply trying to ascertain your observation and relate it to what is written in this particular affidavit that your counsel is referring to, this particular sentence.
Yes, his brains - I did not actually see his brains being blown apart and there is also no physical evidence that his brains were blown apart.
But while you accompanied Mr Kondile did he seem like somebody who was abnormally injured or anything like that?
Let me put it straight.  Did it appear as if he was a person who had the same serious brain injury leading to brain damage?
What are the consequences of this incident Mr Raath, what consequences did it have for you and your family?
This is something which happened to me in my life and I and my family are suffering because of this.  I am very sorry about this, and I will have to carry this burden for the rest of my life.

When you were given the instruction by means of du Plessis' request and you said yes, why did you say "yes you would follow instructions" what was the reason, what was the background?  Why did you execute this instruction?

In the first place where I was working from the morning till the night this unrest and violent situations, what I saw there where I was working as a security policeman on grassroots level and suddenly all things just overwhelmed you.  You can't describe to anybody what type of life you led.  To see schools burning every day.  You send this way, you send that way.  There are trained people who are infiltrating over the borders, they are bringing explosives, ammunitions.  There were bomb attacks, and from my point of view there was absolutely chaos during those time.  This person was definitely identified through interrogation as a trained terrorist, a courier who also assisted in smuggling weapons and explosives and ammunition into the country.  He was working for the ANC in Lesotho.  I can go on and on.
	Taking all these things into consideration it just felt for me that I had to serve the government of the day.  As a policeman I had to do this and I had to assist in maintaining and enforcing law and order and to prevent the unrest situation as far as possible, and I felt this is why I said yes.

Mr Chairman I notice it is precisely one o'clock.  I don't know if you wish to take the luncheon adjournment now.
HEARING ADJOURNS
ON RESUMPTION

(cont)
	Thank you Mr Chairman.  Just to round off Mr Raath, in your written application you have referred to certain political objectives and I am referring to volume 1, page 25, 26 and 27, do you confirm that?  You don't have it in front of you.  It's paragraph 10, A and B, page 25 to 27.

And in paragraph 10 on page 27 you have requested the honourable Commission to the Foundation for Equality before the Law and also van der Merwe's submission, to incorporate that into this application.
	Mr Raath if you want to summarise, what were your political motives when this instruction regarding Mr Kondile was executed?

Your Honour my primary task was that I had sworn allegiance to the State.  I did not do it for my own personal gain, but I acted as a policeman against the liberation movement.  I felt that that what I had done, seen against the background of the unrest situation in the area and in the country was something which was associated with my duties as a policeman.
	My political convictions, I acted in terms of my powers as a member of the South African Police to combat the terrorists and people from the liberation movement.  My activities were in the interest of the country to maintain the government of the day.
After a struggle had been concluded, it doesn't matter where, it's only the people who are the victims.
This was a struggle in which we were involved and I am very sorry for the losses on both sides.

Mr Chairman that is the evidence, thank you.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VISSER
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR BOOYENS
Mr Raath, exactly who was involved in the interrogation of Mr Kondile?
It was I and Captain du Plessis.  He was also interrogated at a stage by member of our East London security branch.
But with regard to interrogations by the Eastern Cape Security branch it was only you and Mr du Plessis, is that correct?
That is correct, as far as I know.

In your application on page 24 Mr Chairman, in your answer to paragraph 9, subsection A(iv) you say that you associate yourself with the statement of Mr du Plessis, in fact you make no statement of your own there, is that correct?

I want to refer you to the corresponding paragraph of Mr du Plessis' affidavit which appears on page 14 of the first bundle, and in particular to the last sentence of the second paragraph thereof, have you found that?  That begins - "since his detention..." etc.  Can you read that sentence.

That is correct.
"Since his detention in the Eastern Cape he was interrogated by myself, members of my personnel as well as members of the Border Security Branch".
I want you to focus on "members of my personnel", it's members in plural and the only member you are referring to is yourself.
That is correct.  I think what he meant there is that Danster was also involved but he was not intensively involved in the interrogation.
To what extent would he have been involved in interrogating?
He was only involved in the guarding of Kondile.
So in fact that's not an application in that Mr Danster was never involved in the interrogation of Mr Kondile, am I right?
So how do you explain this which you have incorporated as part of your statement, what other members of Mr du Plessis' team are being here referred to?
I do not know whether Captain du Plessis referred to the team that worked with him.
Now that we are talking about Mr Danster, it's also stated by Mr Danster that he was amongst the people who went with you to fetch Mr Kondile from Bloemfontein.
In fact the only person you have mentioned to us is a Capt Greyling, is that right?
I take it then it was only the two of you and no one else?
Not the late Mr Buzane and definitely not Mr Danster?
Could you tell us where this Capt Greyling is at the moment, where can we find him?
I have no idea where he is stationed at the moment.
And you've said that you fetched Mr Kondile at the Security Branch in Bloemfontein, is that right?
Who did you deal with in the security branch in Bloemfontein?
In what type of vehicle did you proceed from the Eastern Cape to Bloemfontein ...(intervention)
Is there some doubt about all this?  If there isn't any doubt about it then what is the purpose of these questions?
Mr Chairman it goes back to the question you asked me, which is, our version is that Mr Kondile was abducted from Lesotho.
I am leading up to something with the vehicle, it will become apparent in the next question.  What type of vehicle was used Mr Raath?
It was a sedan, it was Capt Greyling's official vehicle.
So it was not a Datsun Laurel?

You are aware that Mr Danster has made a detailed statement, in fact it was put to you in evidence-in-chief, where he says amongst other things that you went to Bloemfontein and that there was discussion with Mr Kondile on the way back.
No, not at any stage did Danster travel to Bloemfontein with me.
Was there any discussion with Mr Kondile on the way back?
Yes I did speak to him.
Could you tell us what that was about?
At that stage I did not have background, I asked him where he came from and I just spoke to him in general until we reached Port Elizabeth.
It is my instructions, as I have just mentioned to the Chairman, that Mr Kondile was abducted from Lesotho.
Now Mr Danster has said in his statement that Mr Kondile was interrogated over a long period and was subjected to many assaults.
I do not know anything about the assaults.
Could you describe the assaults you do concede to those, that is those by Mr du Plessis.
I was not present when Capt du Plessis assaulted him.  I only heard this here at the trial.
You would agree with me that the arrest of Mr Kondile was a very important event, not so?
I would take it therefore that senior officers and other policemen would have come to Jeffrey's Bay to see the person who has been arrested.
All that I know of is that Capt du Plessis, I worked with him, that he was there.  I didn't see any other officers there.
One of the people that's mentioned by Mr Danster and is agreed to - sorry.  There is mention by Mr Danster of people who came from Pretoria, white policemen.
I do not know about that.
And Mr Coetzee has stated that it was himself who went with Mr van Rensburg at least past this place and certainly saw Mr Kondile at the white single quarters.
I have no knowledge of that.
Do you know whether Mr Dirk Coetzee came there?
No I have no knowledge of that at all.
When you fetched Mr Kondile in Bloemfontein do you know what happened to the vehicle which Mr Kondile had?
At that stage I did not have any knowledge of his vehicle.  I only had the instruction to fetch this man and to take him through to Port Elizabeth.
Mr Raath tell me, you and Mr Danster, were you working in a pair or could it possibly be that he was on duty when you were off at some time during that period of Mr Kondile's detention?
I do not know which stage you are referring to now.
Did you work together or were there occasions when you were off duty and he was on duty?
Yes, we were with him together most of the time.
Do you know when there were occasions when he was alone?
Was he guarded day and night?
Yes.  We all slept there at night and he also slept in the room.  There was a bed for him.
Yes, but you say there were three in the room?
At the time, was there a time when Danster was alone with Kondile?
And where would you be then?
I could have been in Port Elizabeth perhaps busy doing other work or I could even have gone home.
When Mr Kondile was interrogated was it always by you alone or were there times when you would join Mr du Plessis and you would do it together?
There were times that we sat together, there were times when I was alone, when he was alone during the interrogation.
And if Mr du Plessis was there to interrogate Mr Kondile would he also stay over at Jeffrey's Bay?
Most Mr Kondile cooperative from the beginning as far as you were concerned?
As far as I was concerned from the time that I was involved in the operation he gave his cooperation and I had no problems with him.
I am going to put it to you that it's in the highest degree unlikely that you would not have assaulted him and that the version given by Danster is very probable.
You say that Mr du Plessis told you about his decision to recruit Mr Kondile, am I right?
And if I followed your evidence-in-chief properly, he also kept you informed of how that was going?
I would imagine you worked as a security policeman at that point on a need-to-know basis, or am I wrong?

With his recruitment Capt du Plessis did this on his own, I was present while he was doing the interrogation but he was alone with the man at times and in this way he recruited him and he worked with him on his own.
The recruitment occurred while Mr du Plessis was alone with Mr Kondile, is that what you are saying?
Now why would Mr du Plessis come and tell you, a junior officer, about his progress with the recruitment?
He did not elaborate and give me details but I could realise that he was recruiting the man and that there was mutual trust.
Did he also tell you about the note he allegedly found on Mr Kondile?
It was mentioned to me but I was not told the details about the note.
When did you first meet Mr Coetzee?
At the same time, at Komatipoort.
You are telling us of course that Mr van Rensburg never visited, whenever you were present at least, at Jeffrey's Bay?
And the same applies to Mr Erasmus?

Now I am going to take you through from the Eastern Cape to Bloemfontein where supposedly Mr Kondile was released and then abducted or kidnapped.  When it's said that he was released does that mean that he was allowed to leave with his motor vehicle from the police station or did the whole transaction occur of him being kidnapped at the Bloemfontein station?
Sorry.  I think the evidence was that he was released at Jeffrey's Bay, according to the papers at least, if it can be said he was ever released.
I stand corrected.  What actually happened, though, with the vehicle at Bloemfontein, with Mr Kondile's vehicle, did you fetch it immediately from the station and did you get him directly?
The vehicle was handed to me by Capt du Plessis or Colonel van Rensburg, I cannot remember which one of the two it was that gave me the keys of the vehicle.

I am asking this question because Mrs Kondile has brought it to my attention that there seemed to be a number of reports at the time that Mr Kondile was led into his vehicle and was allowed to go, to be released, do you know anything about those?
At Komatipoort itself you say you found the wood already gathered, does that mean the wood was waiting for you?
That is correct.  There was a pile of wood lying there.
And the area which you were in was a remote area, it was unlikely that onlookers would stumble onto what was happening there, am I right?
That's correct, yes.  It's a forestry area.
You have said that Sergeant Otto shot Mr Kondile and you heard the sound, is that right?
That's correct as far as I can remember.
I take it then that a silencer was not used?
That's correct, otherwise I would not have heard the shot.
I put it to you that it's highly unlikely that a silencer would not be used to execute Mr Kondile.
I cannot recall it very well but I cannot think that they used a silencer.
You say that you are unable to recall dates, tell me how you are able to recall the name of Sergeant Otto?
I said that it was a person that I met at the scene and I later refreshed my memory, I remembered the name Roy Otto.
When you refreshed your memory was it with the aid of your co-applicants, that is Mr van Rensburg, Mr Erasmus and Mr du Plessis?

That's correct.  I think I asked one of them whether they could recall who the man was.  I gave a description of the man to you and they, one of them, said that this was Mr Otto and the name rang a bell.
I take it that was the first time you met Mr Otto during this transaction in Komatipoort?
We have heard evidence about various meetings before statements were compiled, were you at any one of those meetings?
Did you read Mr du Plessis' statement before you signed yours?
You just went ahead and signed your statement?
After I went to my legal representatives I compiled my statement and I signed it.
You have described in your evidence your background and what you thought about what you called terrorists, am I right?
You have also told us though that you averted your eyes and tried not to see what was going on, and in fact that you were shocked?
